title: INTRODUCTION TO STATISTICS IN R FOR BIOLOGISTS AND ECOLOGISTS
text:
Dates
17th-20th July 2023
Sign up today


LEARNING OUTCOMES

Understand how to read, interpret and write scripts in R.
Learn statistical tools to address common questions in research activities.
An introduction to efficient, readable and reproducible analyses
Being comfortable with using R when performing both descriptive and inferential statistics.

title: books, workshops & communities
text:
Communities

Biosciences Teaching and Education Research Zenodo Page
A curated output of talks, workshops and teaching innovations from the Biological Sciences Department, University of East Anglia (UEA), Norwich, UK.


Skills Community of Practice
The Skills Community of Practice is an informal forum to share approaches to teaching undergraduate skills with colleagues across institutes. Each month, there is a presentation from a member about their approach to teaching a specific skill or skillset, followed by some whole groups comments/discussion.

The Biology department at the University of East Anglia (UEA) is developing R into teaching at both undergraduate and postgraduate levels. As big data and complex analysis skills become more mainstream across all biological disciplines (from multi-omics to complex ecological datasets), biology students need to have skills in computer programming and data analysis. The curriculum now prioritises the essential analytical skills in “data science”, including developing programming skills, data visualisation techniques, data wrangling, and creating reproducible reports. Providing students with the data handling tools to problem solve across various biological disciplines and beyond. This website is a repository for the open materials used in teaching reproducible research within the Biology department at UEA. For access to open data and code, please visit our GitHub page.

title: teaching resources
text:
Reporting analyses

How to report analysis results: A published guide on the approproate way to report results from a statistical test.
Reporting statistical methods: A great paper on the necessary level of detail in methods reporting, a how-to-guide






Reproducible science

Guides to reproducible code: The British Ecological Society guide to making reproducible code
Society for Open, Reliable, and Transparent Ecology and Evolutionary biology: This organisation produces a reading list on how to make better reproducible science
